documentation_categories.name: Materials
documentation_categories.description: Information about leather and other materials

documentation_resources.title: Welcome to HideSync
documentation_resources.description: Introduction to the HideSync leatherworking ERP system
documentation_resources.content:
# Welcome to HideSync

HideSync is a comprehensive ERP system designed specifically for leatherworkers, from individual artisans to small-scale manufacturing operations.

## Key Features

- **Inventory Management**: Track your leathers, hardware, and supplies
- **Project Management**: Manage your custom and production projects
- **Customer Management**: Keep track of your customers and their preferences
- **Sales & Orders**: Manage sales from various channels

Get started by exploring the main navigation menu on the left side of the screen.
documentation_resources.author: HideSync Team

documentation_resources.title: Understanding Leather Types
documentation_resources.description: Comprehensive guide to leather types and their properties
documentation_resources.content:
# Understanding Leather Types

This guide covers the main types of leather used in leatherworking projects and their characteristics.

## Vegetable Tanned Leather

Vegetable tanned leather is tanned using natural tannins from plant materials. It's known for:

- Natural color that develops a patina over time
- Ability to be tooled, molded, and shaped when wet
- Firmer feel compared to chrome tanned leather
- Environmental sustainability

## Chrome Tanned Leather

Chrome tanned leather uses chromium salts in the tanning process. It's characterized by:

- Soft, supple feel right from the start
- Wide range of vibrant colors
- Water resistance
- Less prone to water staining

## Oil Tanned Leather

Oil tanned leather has oils added during the tanning process, resulting in:

- Very soft, supple feel
- Good water resistance
- Pull-up effect (color changes when stretched)
- Low maintenance

When adding new materials to your inventory, be sure to select the correct leather type to help with project planning.
documentation_resources.author: HideSync Team

documentation_resources.title: Essential Leatherworking Tools
documentation_resources.description: An overview of basic tools needed to start leatherworking.
documentation_resources.content:
# Essential Leatherworking Tools

Starting leathercraft requires a few key tools. Here's a basic list:

- **Cutting Mat:** Self-healing mat to protect your work surface and blade.
- **Utility Knife / Craft Knife:** Sharp blade for cutting leather (e.g., X-Acto, Stanley).
- **Metal Ruler / Straight Edge:** For guiding cuts.
- **Stitching Chisels / Pricking Irons:** To create holes for stitching (diamond, french, etc.).
- **Mallet / Maul:** Rawhide, poly, or wooden mallet for striking tools (chisels, stamps).
- **Harness Needles:** Blunt-tipped needles for hand stitching.
- **Waxed Thread:** Durable thread designed for leather (polyester, linen).
- **Edge Beveler:** Removes the sharp corner from leather edges.
- **Burnisher:** Smooths and seals leather edges (wood, plastic, bone folder).
- **Optional:** Skiving knife, hole punches, stamps, dye, applicators.
documentation_resources.author: HideSync Team

documentation_resources.title: Cutting Leather Accurately
documentation_resources.description: Tips for getting clean, straight cuts in leather.
documentation_resources.content:
# Cutting Leather Accurately

Clean cuts are fundamental to professional-looking leather goods.

1.  **Sharp Blade:** Always use a very sharp blade. Dull blades drag and tear leather. Snap-off utility knives are convenient.
2.  **Secure the Leather:** Place the leather grain-side up on a cutting mat. Ensure it doesn't shift.
3.  **Use a Metal Ruler:** Place a heavy metal ruler firmly along your cutting line.
4.  **Multiple Passes:** Don't try to cut through thick leather in one pass. Make several light, controlled passes, keeping the blade vertical against the ruler.
5.  **Start and Stop:** Begin your cut slightly before the start line and end slightly after the end line for clean corners when cutting out patterns.
6.  **Curves:** For curves, use a sharp round knife or make multiple small, straight cuts tangent to the curve with a utility knife.
documentation_resources.author: HideSync Team

documentation_resources.title: Preparing Leather for Hand Stitching
documentation_resources.content:
# Preparing Leather for Hand Stitching

Consistent stitching starts with proper preparation.

1.  **Mark Stitch Line:** Use wing dividers or a groover to mark a consistent line parallel to the edge where your stitches will go.
2.  **Choose Your Tool:** Decide between stitching chisels (create diamond-shaped holes) or pricking irons (mark stitch locations, holes punched later with an awl). Spacing is measured in SPI (Stitches Per Inch) or millimeters.
3.  **Punching Holes (Chisels):**
    *   Place leather on a poundo board or scrap leather.
    *   Align the chisel on the stitch line, ensuring it's perpendicular to the surface.
    *   Strike firmly with a mallet. Ensure the chisel goes all the way through.
    *   For the next set of holes, place the first tooth of the chisel in the last hole made.
4.  **Marking Holes (Pricking Irons):**
    *   Mark lightly with the pricking iron along the stitch line.
    *   Use a stitching awl (diamond or round) to pierce the holes fully, following the marks, often done during the stitching process itself.

Consistency is key for a neat stitch line.
documentation_resources.author: HideSync Team

documentation_resources.title: The Saddle Stitch
documentation_resources.description: How to perform the basic and durable hand stitch for leather.
documentation_resources.content:
# The Saddle Stitch

The saddle stitch is the most common and durable hand stitch for leather. It uses two needles on a single thread.

1.  **Measure Thread:** Measure thread about 3-4 times the length of the seam you're stitching.
2.  **Thread Needles:** Thread a harness needle onto each end of the thread. Lock the thread onto the needle (pass needle through thread, pull tight).
3.  **Start Stitching:** Push one needle through the first hole. Pull the thread through until equal lengths are on both sides.
4.  **First Stitch:** Push the left needle through the second hole. Pull the thread snug, but not tight.
5.  **Second Needle:** Push the right needle through the *same* second hole. Be careful *not* to pierce the thread already in the hole. Wiggle the needle or use an awl to open the hole slightly if needed. Pull the right thread through.
6.  **Set the Stitch:** Pull both threads simultaneously outwards and slightly upwards/downwards (depending on preference) to set the stitch evenly in the hole. Consistency in how you pass the needles (e.g., left needle first, right needle second *behind* the first thread) and how you pull tight is crucial for a uniform look.
7.  **Continue:** Repeat steps 4-6 for all holes.
8.  **Backstitch:** To finish, stitch backward 2-3 holes for security.
9.  **Trim and Melt:** Cut the threads close to the surface. If using polyester thread, carefully melt the ends with a lighter to prevent unraveling.
documentation_resources.author: HideSync Team

documentation_resources.title: Basic Edge Finishing
documentation_resources.description: Introduction to beveling and burnishing leather edges.
documentation_resources.content:
# Basic Edge Finishing

Finishing the edges elevates the look and durability of leather goods.

1.  **Level Edges:** Ensure the edges to be finished are flush and even. Sand lightly if necessary.
2.  **Beveling:** Use an edge beveler tool appropriate for your leather thickness. Hold it at a consistent angle (often ~45 degrees) and run it along the corners of the edge (both top and bottom) to remove the sharp corner, creating a rounded profile. Use smooth, controlled strokes.
3.  **Applying Agent (Optional but Recommended):** Apply water, gum tragacanth, or a dedicated burnishing agent (like Tokonole) sparingly along the beveled edge.
4.  **Burnishing:** Rub the edge vigorously with a wood slicker, canvas cloth, or bone folder. The friction and pressure (and burnishing agent) compress the leather fibers, darkening and smoothing the edge, creating a sealed, glossy finish.
5.  **Repeat if Needed:** You may need multiple applications of agent and burnishing for a perfect result.
6.  **Waxing (Optional):** For extra protection and shine, rub beeswax onto the burnished edge and buff with a cloth.
documentation_resources.author: HideSync Team
